Mr. Brooks' editorials of late have been a bit - how shall I put it -- weird. This one ascends to new heights of weirdness.

Interesting that his first idea is to emulate the Koch brothers - but they are of course not the selfless supporters of "independent thought" he pretends . They are indeed the ones who urge their candidates ever deeper into the "fever swamps".

But then, on to "friends" and the supposed social and political benefits of having "friends". He is vastly over-romanticizing what the "average" friends are all about - drinking buddies, guys to go to ball games with or share other (mostly) sporting interests, or girls to go shopping with or to have "girl-talk" times, most often with people who reflect, mirror and reenforce ones own idiosyncrasies and prejudices, social, political, religious and otherwise.

Mr. Brooks' "adult camps or retreat centers" sound a little like the communes of the 60's, but with a bit of the upper-crust, boarding school, golf-club twist to it -- "eating the meals would go on for a while", "read about and discuss big topics", "play sports", and then of course the capper - "At night, there’d be a bar and music." How idyllic!

His goal that "Groups ... would be brought together from all social and demographic groups" is, I guess, where the $500 million comes in - the "lower" social and demographic groups would have to be paid to be able to attend such idyllic "adult camps or retreat centers", for how else could they afford it.

my intention was to suggest that higher education may offer opportunities to appreciate cultural alternatives. that is, alternatives to individuals' "native" cultures. though, i must admit that, the contemporary university approach of extreme disciplinary specialization and utilitarianism may not foster that quality of growth. often we aren't equipped to make, or even consider, lifestyle changes until we become aware that alternatives exist, and that some might, in fact, be be "better". peterson's assertion/justification that his form of discipline is the "way he was raised", to me suggests that he has never even considered alternatives.

trust me, i'm well aware that higher-education is not a panacea, even to developing a, well-rounded, general-knowledge. but, education is always a critical component of any growth. consider that, upon arrest, or conviction, for domestic violence, one of the first conditions is attending anger-management counseling sessions. is an educative approach to behavioral alternatives not a vital element of these sessions? what you call "training", is in fact education that exploits the strategy of practical-application.

as for football, i must maintain that the "violence" of that sport is not a causative factor. though i have no data to support it, my expectation is that the NBA has issues quite similar to the NFL.

and, then there's the blade runner!

Steve Forbes discusses his book, Money, on Book TV, 6/18/2014.: "... since the early 70s, even though we've had booming decades in the 80s & 90s, overall, since we went off the Bretton Woods system, the old gold standard, in 1971, the U.S. average growth rates are less than they were before 1971. If we'd maintained the growth rates we had for 180 years up to 1971, if we'd maintained those growth rates after 1971, on average, the U.S. economy today would be 50% larger than it is now.  Forty years compounding adds up to a lot. ... This thing over time adds up.  It's a critical reason why it takes two incomes in a family, to do what one income could do in previous generations.  Obviously, taxes are a large part of it, but the debasement of the dollar since the early 70s is a critical part of it as well.  And when this thing happens, when you don't have a stable currency, you end up with people not getting ahead the way they should, median incomes not growing the way they should, and leading to a fraying of the social fabric, reduction of social trust, and more divisions.  As Keynes said, it's a process that not one in a million will be able to diagnose."

There is hope, and I hope it isn't too late to turn the tide. These reports are very good news. Now to convince the negative members of our society.

The negativism is of a general nature, and when one can't feel positive, or the positivism is constantly tarnished, despair sets in. Despair is the new economics of our cultural starvation diet. My point is that we allow free flow of capital and goods, but not labor. We have freedom for our inanimate wealth, but not for people.

If we can't take them, then we must re-examine the freedom to take money out, to push trade in that underprices them where they are, leaving them trapped there with nothing.

Globalize or don't glaboalize, but not globalize for me but not for thee.

Economic refugees are a problem of globalization, like ruined Mexican farmers who can't compete with our Big Ag but can't leave either.

We are inconsistent about globalization, always in favor of our richest and against the poorest people trying to flee the consequences.

Personally, I don't buy the whole neo-liberal line, or unlimited total globalization. Limited market and industrial protections and limited product substitution are healthy for economies. Limited. See Japan and Singapore, etc, who did exactly that with great success. China is doing it now, again with great success. Germany does it, in a slightly different way.

Even worse is to do that, then trap people in it, the one part of the economy that isn't free to move globally in trade.

Refugees from war are a different subject. We already handle them differently.

A carbon fee and dividend is the easiest way to drastically reduce CO2 emissions. And even without counting the benefits of the reduction in CO2 emissions, it is a win for the economy and for public health.

Regional Economic Modeling, Inc. (REMI) conducted a nation-wide macroeconomic study for Citizens' Climate Lobby (CCL) on the impacts of CCL's carbon fee and dividend (F&D) policy.

The tax on carbon was either $0 from 2016-2035 (the baseline), or was $10 per ton in 2016 and increased by $10 every year after that (F&D).

CO2 emissions decline 33% after only 10 years, and 52% after 20 years relative to the baseline ($0/ton of CO2).

National employment increases by 2.1 million jobs after 10 years, and 2.8 million after 20 years. This is more than a 1% increase in total US employment we don't get without a carbon tax.

Real incomes increase by more than $500 per person in 2025. This increase accounts for cost of living increases.

Over the first 10 years, 13,000 lives are saved annually, with a cumulative 227,000 American lives saved over 20 years.

Not included in the report are the benefits that are the raison d'être of the fee and dividend, the reductions in the costs associated with anthropogenic global warming and anthropogenic climate change.

So I think the first step is understanding what an "inverse function" is. Some of the ideas above are a little muddled. Inverse functions aren't really about "order matters". But they are definitely about "can be reversed".

We say that g(x) = x + 1 is an "inverse function" of h(x) = x - 1. Stated differently, "adding 1" and "subtracting 1" are inverses. If you do one of these, then do the other, you get back to where you started. Adding one "undoes" subtracting one, and vice-versa.

When Cosman Frog ponds are combined, their populations are basically multiplied. However, PRIOR to the multiplication step we add one, and AFTER the multiplication step we subtract one. The Cosman Frog Product of ponds of size a and b is [(a+1) * (b+1)] - 1. This works because the adding one and subtracting one are inverse functions. The Fendel Frog Product is similar, except switching the adding and subtracting: [(a-1) * (b-1)] + 1.

"Adding one" and "subtracting one" are not the only inverse functions. "Multiply by 10" and "divide by 10" are inverses. "Squared" and "square-root" are inverses. For any pair of inverses, we can create a frog species which combines in this way. Consider "multiply by 10" and "divide by 10". The frog product associated with these would be [(10a) * (10b)] / 10, which simplifies to 10*a*b. The first challenge was to create a story that illustrates this. For this example, how could you describe frog families combining such that the result is 10*a*b?

OK. Cool. Here's an initial attempt. a frogs and b frogs each invite nine friends to a romantic frog event. Some time later 10a×10b, or 100ab, frogs are born, but only a tenth survive, yielding 10ab frog kids. Parents die, 10ab frogs are left.

This is the same as if a frogs and b frogs generate ab offspring, die, and their ab froglets each invite 9 friends to the funeral, creating a total 10ab gathered (living) frogs.

Joe #26,

I'm trying to get a feel for your challenge and am not quite there. So far it seems --

I can put apples, bananas and carrots in a bag, and it doesn't matter which fruit goes in first. I can also put in any two fruits at once. Once I'm done I can take out in any order and combination. The process can be reversed and order/grouping doesn't matter.

Some processes can't be reversed and order/grouping doesn't matter (too much!): making a smoothie.

Some processes can be reversed but order matters: I put on socks then shoes but must take off shoes then socks.

Finally - some processes can't be reversed but order matters: making a cake.

But I can't quite make the leap to your challenge. Could you give a very simple example?

Physics is the set of rules that govern matter and energy. The rules of physics would exist even if there were no sentient beings to observe them. If we were all to perish, the rules, matter, and energy, would persist.

The rules of physics and matter and energy existed forever. There was no 'beginning' for matter, energy, and the rules of physics. Perhaps there was a 'big bang' 15 billion years ago, causing the restructuring of matter and energy in the form we know as our universe. The matter and energy existed before the big bang, perhaps in a different form. But there was no time before matter, energy, and the rules of physics existed,

It is easy to believe this because there is no alternative.

Deists insist that nothing could have existed forever, there must have been a beginning, and god created everything, totally unwilling to recognize the obvious contradiction by exempting god from the 'nothing could exist forever' axiom.

It really is easy.

1) Matter, energy, and the rules of physics existed forever,

2) The universe may get restructured from time to time.

3) Life evolves after a restructuring.

4) Sentient beings are a product of evolution.

5) The belief in god is a product of evolution.

The best bike lane in the older Manhattan was the center stripe up Madison Ave that separated the bus lanes from the car lanes. Smooth, white, non slip it was about two feet wide and was a great lane for those with the skill to use it.

What is noteworthy is that the so-called bicycle lanes in most American towns and cities would not even count as such in Amsterdam or other large Dutch cities. There on busy streets bike lanes are separated from traffic and from pedestrians by curbs and greenery and signs warn of bike paths (feetspad). There are rules of the road for bicyclists and drivers that are highly functional and both cyclists and drivers observe them. It is highly romantic nonsense to think that this could work in Manhattan where there is too much traffic and too little space for bike paths in most of the island below 110th St. In many American cities and in large parts of the outer boroughs of NY though bike paths could work but efforts at rules and their enforcement as well as the necessary construction and arrangements and markings are so seriously neglected as to cause one to wonder whether there is a serious civic will to make this work.

It is cheap because, like any investment, there is a rate of return on the money spent. Solar system prices continue to decline and the very real money saved in lower electric bills lowers the cost of going green.  Big oil and coal stand to lose trillions if we stop using their products and they don't mind spending millions to insure their continuing profit stream.  Remove their negative propaganda from the debate and the change to green energy would accelerate rather quickly.  Clean air and water, lower mercury levels in fish and decreased acidification of our lakes and ocean would be added bonuses.  Miami Beach is already having to spend millions because of salt water intrusion.  Insurance rates rise every year because of increases fire and weather casualty risks.  There are other very real costs to continuing to use fossil fuels that we won't see until it's too late.  Add in these savings and changing to green energy becomes much less costly, and some might say, "free."

It seems rather needlessly complex to defend the value of taking a stand on something for which there simply isn't much in the way of convincing evidence.  It would be far simpler to simply view the matter as unresolved and to take particular views, theist or atheist, as matters of preference, albeit strongly held.  It is difficult to see how the energy expended on taking a stand without the requisite knowledge is useful.  Does it really lead to better discussions?  It's difficult to see why this should be the case but then this appears to yet another matter of opinion.  Could we end up discussing an endless and unproductive series of unresolved matters.  To what end?  Forgive me but is this whole discussion really "much ado about nothing"?  It seems to be nothing more than a version of the well-worn muddling of faith and science.  Haven't we had enough of this sort of thing?  The two can coexist quite harmoniously if faith doesn't make claims that contradict science when science has good evidence and science doesn't take positions on matters of faith for which clear evidence is lacking.  Mix in a bit of flexibility all around so that perspectives can evolve over time as evidence evolves... and all can live happily ever after!

@DGA....yes, let's define  'austerity'. The question is why Krugman does not cite the investments in infrastructure Germany and other countries make. Tell what they're doing, so as to offer practical positive examples of just what he seems to advocate--coming to terms with climate change, through govt action.

That this is possible has been demonstrated already:

From the Economist, Oct 12, 2013:

"ON JUNE 16th something very peculiar happened in Germany’s electricity market. The wholesale price of electricity fell to minus €100 per megawatt hour (MWh). That is, generating companies were having to pay the managers of the grid to take their electricity. Between 2pm and 3pm, solar and wind generators produced 28.9 gigawatts (GW) of power, more than half the total. The grid at that time could not cope with more than 45GW without becoming unstable. At the peak, total generation was over 51GW; so prices went negative to encourage cutbacks ..."

The same article shows the wholesale price of electricity, in Euros per MWh, falling from 60 in 2011 to 37 in 2013. Yes, falling.

Germany is a highly industrialized state that runs on energy. It is also a state that invest in infrastructure, with solar panels on many roofs - and a country with a positive budget balance and no deficit spending .

And it just set a new record in exports and trade surplus. [1]

Could it be that there is something to " austerity" after all ?
